     <p>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
       Etymology
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Singapore" title="Names of Singapore">
       Names of Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The English name of Singapore is an
      <a href="/wiki/Anglicisation" title="Anglicisation">
       anglicisation
      </a>
      of the native
      <a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">
       Malay
      </a>
      name for the country,
      <i>
       <span lang="ms">
        Singapura
       </span>
      </i>
      , which was in turn derived from
      <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">
       Sanskrit
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
       <a href="#cite_note-13">
        [13]
       </a>
      </sup>
      (
      <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E0%A4%B8%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%82%E0%A4%B9%E0%A4%AA%E0%A5%81%E0%A4%B0" title="wikt:सिंहपुर">
       सिंहपुर
      </a>
      ,
      <small>
       <a href="/wiki/International_Alphabet_of_Sanskrit_Transliteration" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">
        IAST
       </a>
      </small>
      :
      <i>
       <b>
        Siṃhapura
       </b>
      </i>
      ;
      <i>
       siṃha
      </i>
      is "lion",
      <i>
       pura
      </i>
      is "town" or "city"), hence the customary reference to the nation as the
      <i>
       Lion City
      </i>
      , and its inclusion in many of the nation's symbols (e.g., its coat of arms, Merlion emblem). However, it is unlikely that
      <a href="/wiki/Lion" title="Lion">
       lions
      </a>
      ever lived on the island;
      <a href="/wiki/Sang_Nila_Utama" title="Sang Nila Utama">
       Sang Nila Utama
      </a>
      , who founded and named the island
      <i>
       Singapura
      </i>
      , most likely saw a
      <a href="/wiki/Malayan_tiger" title="Malayan tiger">
       Malayan tiger
      </a>
      . The central island has also been called
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Pulau_Ujong" title="Pulau Ujong">
        Pulau Ujong
       </a>
      </i>
      as far back as the 3rd century, literally "island at the end" (of the
      <a href="/wiki/Malay_Peninsula" title="Malay Peninsula">
       Malay Peninsula
      </a>
      ) in Malay.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
       <a href="#cite_note-14">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
       <a href="#cite_note-15">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
       History
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_Singapore" title="History of Singapore">
       History of Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Evacuation_of_British_POWs,_Kallang_Airport,_Singapore_-_19450908.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="759" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Evacuation_of_British_POWs%2C_Kallang_Airport%2C_Singapore_-_19450908.jpg/170px-Evacuation_of_British_POWs%2C_Kallang_Airport%2C_Singapore_-_19450908.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Evacuation_of_British_POWs%2C_Kallang_Airport%2C_Singapore_-_19450908.jpg/255px-Evacuation_of_British_POWs%2C_Kallang_Airport%2C_Singapore_-_19450908.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Evacuation_of_British_POWs%2C_Kallang_Airport%2C_Singapore_-_19450908.jpg/340px-Evacuation_of_British_POWs%2C_Kallang_Airport%2C_Singapore_-_19450908.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Evacuation_of_British_POWs,_Kallang_Airport,_Singapore_-_19450908.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        British
        <a href="/wiki/Prisoner_of_war" title="Prisoner of war">
         POWs
        </a>
        evacuation after the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_surrender" title="Japanese surrender">
         Japanese surrender
        </a>
        in 1945.
        <a href="/wiki/Kallang_Airport" title="Kallang Airport">
         Kallang Airport
        </a>
        control tower still stands, opposite the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singapore_National_Stadium" title="Singapore National Stadium">
         National Stadium
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 1299, according to the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Malay_Annals" title="Malay Annals">
        Malay Annals
       </a>
      </i>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Singapura" title="Kingdom of Singapura">
       Kingdom of Singapura
      </a>
      was established on the island as a trading port city. There were two major foreign invasions before it was destroyed by the
      <a href="/wiki/Majapahit" title="Majapahit">
       Majapahit
      </a>
      in 1398.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harvnb.7CSabrizain_3-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-harvnb.7CSabrizain-3">
        [3]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tsang_2011_120_5-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Tsang_2011_120-5">
        [5]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
       <a href="#cite_note-16">
        [16]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1613,
      <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">
       Portuguese
      </a>
      raiders burned down the settlement, which by then was nominally part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Johor_Sultanate" title="Johor Sultanate">
       Johor Sultanate
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-country_studies_17-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-country_studies-17">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The wider maritime region and much trade was under Dutch control for the following period.
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1819,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thomas_Stamford_Raffles" title="Thomas Stamford Raffles">
       Thomas Stamford Raffles
      </a>
      arrived and signed a treaty with
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultan_Hussein_Shah" title="Sultan Hussein Shah">
       Sultan Hussein Shah
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/Johor" title="Johor">
       Johor
      </a>
      , on behalf of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_East_India_Company" title="British East India Company">
       British East India Company
      </a>
      , to develop the southern part of Singapore as a
      <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">
       British
      </a>
      trading post. In 1824, the entire island, as well as the
      <a href="/wiki/Temenggung" title="Temenggung">
       Temenggong
      </a>
      , became a British possession after a further treaty with the Sultan.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Founding_of_Modern_Singapore_18-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Founding_of_Modern_Singapore-18">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1826, Singapore became part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Straits_Settlements" title="Straits Settlements">
       Straits Settlements
      </a>
      , under the jurisdiction of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_India" title="British India">
       British India
      </a>
      , becoming the regional capital in 1836.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
       <a href="#cite_note-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Prior to Raffles' arrival, there were only about a thousand people living on the island, mostly
      <a href="/wiki/Orang_Asal" title="Orang Asal">
       indigenous Malays
      </a>
      along with a handful of
      <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people" title="Chinese people">
       Chinese
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Malays_20-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-The_Malays-20">
        [20]
       </a>
      </sup>
      By 1860, the population had swelled to more than 80,000 and more than half were Chinese. Many immigrants came to work at
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rubber" title="Rubber">
       rubber
      </a>
      plantations and, after the 1870s, the island became a global centre for rubber exports.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Founding_of_Modern_Singapore_18-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Founding_of_Modern_Singapore-18">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      After the
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
       First World War
      </a>
      , the British built the large
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Naval_Base" title="Singapore Naval Base">
       Singapore Naval Base
      </a>
      as part of the defensive
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_strategy" title="Singapore strategy">
       Singapore strategy
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      During the
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
       Second World War
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army" title="Imperial Japanese Army">
       Imperial Japanese Army
      </a>
      invaded
      <a href="/wiki/British_Malaya" title="British Malaya">
       British Malaya
      </a>
      , culminating in the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Singapore" title="Battle of Singapore">
       Battle of Singapore
      </a>
      . When the British force of 60,000 troops surrendered on 15 February 1942, British Prime Minister
      <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">
       Winston Churchill
      </a>
      called the defeat "the worst disaster and largest capitulation in British history.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
       <a href="#cite_note-21">
        [21]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Between 5,000 and 25,000 ethnic Chinese people were killed in the subsequent
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sook_Ching_massacre" title="Sook Ching massacre">
       Sook Ching massacre
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
       <a href="#cite_note-22">
        [22]
       </a>
      </sup>
      From November 1944 to May 1945, the Allies conducted an intensive
      <a href="/wiki/Bombing_of_Singapore_(1944%E2%80%9345)" title="Bombing of Singapore (1944–45)">
       bombing of Singapore
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_Occupation_of_Singapore" title="Japanese Occupation of Singapore">
       Japanese occupied Singapore
      </a>
      until the
      <a href="/wiki/Operation_Tiderace" title="Operation Tiderace">
       British repossessed
      </a>
      it in September 1945, after the
      <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">
       Surrender of Japan
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
       <a href="#cite_note-23">
        [23]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_during_the_formation_of_Malaysia_(16_September_1963).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="424" data-file-width="639" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Singapore_during_the_formation_of_Malaysia_%2816_September_1963%29.jpg/220px-Singapore_during_the_formation_of_Malaysia_%2816_September_1963%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Singapore_during_the_formation_of_Malaysia_%2816_September_1963%29.jpg/330px-Singapore_during_the_formation_of_Malaysia_%2816_September_1963%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Singapore_during_the_formation_of_Malaysia_%2816_September_1963%29.jpg/440px-Singapore_during_the_formation_of_Malaysia_%2816_September_1963%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_during_the_formation_of_Malaysia_(16_September_1963).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The founding father of modern Singapore,
        <a href="/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew" title="Lee Kuan Yew">
         Lee Kuan Yew
        </a>
        declaring the formation of the Federation of Malaysia on 16 September 1963 in Singapore.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      During the 1950s, Chinese communists with strong ties to the trade unions and Chinese schools waged a guerrilla war against the government, leading to the
      <a href="/wiki/Malayan_Emergency" title="Malayan Emergency">
       Malayan Emergency
      </a>
      . The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1954_National_Service_Riots" title="1954 National Service Riots">
       1954 National Service Riots
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Chinese_middle_schools_riots" title="Chinese middle schools riots">
       Chinese middle schools riots
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Hock_Lee_bus_riots" title="Hock Lee bus riots">
       Hock Lee bus riots
      </a>
      in Singapore were all linked to these events.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        [24]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/David_Marshall_(Singaporean_politician)" title="David Marshall (Singaporean politician)">
       David Marshall
      </a>
      , pro-independence leader of the
      <a href="/wiki/Labour_Front" title="Labour Front">
       Labour Front
      </a>
      , won Singapore's first general election in 1955. He led a delegation to London, but Britain rejected his demand for complete self-rule. He resigned and was replaced by
      <a href="/wiki/Lim_Yew_Hock" title="Lim Yew Hock">
       Lim Yew Hock
      </a>
      , whose policies convinced Britain to grant Singapore full internal
      <a href="/wiki/Self-governance_of_Singapore" title="Self-governance of Singapore">
       self-government
      </a>
      for all matters except defence and foreign affairs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
       <a href="#cite_note-25">
        [25]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      During the
      <a href="/wiki/Singaporean_general_election,_1959" title="Singaporean general election, 1959">
       May 1959 elections
      </a>
      , the People's Action Party won a landslide victory. Singapore became an internally self-governing state within the Commonwealth, with
      <a href="/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew" title="Lee Kuan Yew">
       Lee Kuan Yew
      </a>
      as its first Prime Minister.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yewnyt_26-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-yewnyt-26">
        [26]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Governor_of_Singapore" title="Governor of Singapore">
       Governor
      </a>
      Sir
      <a href="/wiki/William_Allmond_Codrington_Goode" title="William Allmond Codrington Goode">
       William Allmond Codrington Goode
      </a>
      served as the first
      <a href="/wiki/Yang_di-Pertuan_Negara" title="Yang di-Pertuan Negara">
       Yang di-Pertuan Negara
      </a>
      (Head of State), and was succeeded by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yusof_bin_Ishak" title="Yusof bin Ishak">
       Yusof bin Ishak
      </a>
      , who became the first President of Singapore in 1965.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Law_27-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Law-27">
        [27]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      As a result of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1962_Merger_Referendum_of_Singapore" title="1962 Merger Referendum of Singapore">
       1962 Merger Referendum
      </a>
      , on 16 September 1963
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_in_Malaysia" title="Singapore in Malaysia">
       Singapore
      </a>
      joined with the
      <a href="/wiki/Federation_of_Malaya" title="Federation of Malaya">
       Federation of Malaya
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Crown_Colony_of_Sarawak" title="Crown Colony of Sarawak">
       Crown Colony of Sarawak
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Crown_Colony_of_North_Borneo" title="Crown Colony of North Borneo">
       Crown Colony of North Borneo
      </a>
      to form the new federation of
      <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">
       Malaysia
      </a>
      under the terms of the
      <a href="/wiki/Malaysia_Agreement" title="Malaysia Agreement">
       Malaysia Agreement
      </a>
      . Singaporean leaders chose to join Malaysia primarily due to concerns over its limited land size, scarcity of water, markets and natural resources. Some Singaporean and Malaysian politicians were also concerned that the communists might form the government on the island, a possibility perceived as an external threat to the Federation of Malaya.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      However, shortly after the merger, the Singapore state government and the Malaysian central government disagreed on many political and economic issues, and communal strife culminated in the
      <a href="/wiki/1964_race_riots_in_Singapore" title="1964 race riots in Singapore">
       1964 race riots in Singapore
      </a>
      . After many
      <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party%E2%80%93United_Malays_National_Organisation_relations" title="People's Action Party–United Malays National Organisation relations">
       heated ideological conflicts between the two governments
      </a>
      , on 9 August 1965, the Malaysian Parliament voted 126 to 0 to expel Singapore from Malaysia with Singaporean delegates not present.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LOC2_8-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-LOC2-8">
        [8]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
       <a href="#cite_note-28">
        [28]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
       <a href="#cite_note-29">
        [29]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_Night_Perspective_on_the_Singapore_Merlion_(8347645113).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1308" data-file-width="1962" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/A_Night_Perspective_on_the_Singapore_Merlion_%288347645113%29.jpg/220px-A_Night_Perspective_on_the_Singapore_Merlion_%288347645113%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/A_Night_Perspective_on_the_Singapore_Merlion_%288347645113%29.jpg/330px-A_Night_Perspective_on_the_Singapore_Merlion_%288347645113%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/A_Night_Perspective_on_the_Singapore_Merlion_%288347645113%29.jpg/440px-A_Night_Perspective_on_the_Singapore_Merlion_%288347645113%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A_Night_Perspective_on_the_Singapore_Merlion_(8347645113).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A symbol of Singapore, the
        <a href="/wiki/Merlion" title="Merlion">
         Merlion
        </a>
        was created in 1964
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Singapore gained independence as the Republic of Singapore (remaining within the
      <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">
       Commonwealth of Nations
      </a>
      ) on 9 August 1965.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LOC2_8-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-LOC2-8">
        [8]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Race riots
      <a href="/wiki/1969_race_riots_of_Singapore" title="1969 race riots of Singapore">
       broke out once more
      </a>
      in 1969. In 1967, the country co-founded
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASEAN" title="ASEAN">
       ASEAN
      </a>
      , the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
       <a href="#cite_note-30">
        [30]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew" title="Lee Kuan Yew">
       Lee Kuan Yew
      </a>
      became Prime Minister, and the country moved from
      <a href="/wiki/Third_World" title="Third World">
       Third World
      </a>
      economy to
      <a href="/wiki/First_World" title="First World">
       First World
      </a>
      affluence in a single generation. Lee Kuan Yew's emphasis on rapid economic growth, support for business entrepreneurship, and limitations on internal democracy shaped Singapore's policies for the next half-century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
       <a href="#cite_note-31">
        [31]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lky-7prin_32-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-lky-7prin-32">
        [32]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1990,
      <a href="/wiki/Goh_Chok_Tong" title="Goh Chok Tong">
       Goh Chok Tong
      </a>
      succeeded Lee as Prime Minister, while the latter continued serving in the Cabinet as
      <a href="/wiki/Senior_Minister" title="Senior Minister">
       Senior Minister
      </a>
      until 2004, and then
      <a href="/wiki/Minister_Mentor" title="Minister Mentor">
       Minister Mentor
      </a>
      until May 2011. During Goh's tenure, the country faced the
      <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">
       1997 Asian financial crisis
      </a>
      , the 2003
      <a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome">
       SARS
      </a>
      outbreak and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Terrorist" title="Terrorist">
       terrorist
      </a>
      threats posed by
      <a href="/wiki/Jemaah_Islamiyah" title="Jemaah Islamiyah">
       Jemaah Islamiyah
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2004,
      <a href="/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong" title="Lee Hsien Loong">
       Lee Hsien Loong
      </a>
      , the eldest son of Lee Kuan Yew, became the country's third Prime Minister. Goh Chok Tong remained in Cabinet as the Senior Minister until May 2011, when he was named Emeritus Senior Minister despite his retirement. Lee Hsien Loong's tenure included the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_global_financial_crisis" title="2008 global financial crisis">
       2008 global financial crisis
      </a>
      , the resolution of a dispute over
      <a href="/wiki/Tanjong_Pagar_railway_station" title="Tanjong Pagar railway station">
       Malayan railways land
      </a>
      , and the introduction of
      <a href="/wiki/Integrated_resort" title="Integrated resort">
       integrated resorts
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
       <a href="#cite_note-33">
        [33]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Despite the economy's exceptional growth, the
      <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party" title="People's Action Party">
       People's Action Party
      </a>
      (PAP) suffered its
      <a href="/wiki/Singaporean_general_election,_2011" title="Singaporean general election, 2011">
       worst election results
      </a>
      in 2011, winning 60% of votes, amidst hot-button issues of high influx of foreign workers and cost of living.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      On 23 March 2015 Lee Kuan Yew died,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lky-7prin_32-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-lky-7prin-32">
        [32]
       </a>
      </sup>
      during the 50th year of independence. Subsequently, the PAP maintained its dominance in Parliament at the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GE2015" title="GE2015">
       September general elections
      </a>
      , receiving 69.9% of the popular vote, its second-highest polling result behind the 2001 tally of 75.3%.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">
       Government and politics
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Singapore" title="Government of Singapore">
       Government of Singapore
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Singapore" title="Politics of Singapore">
       Politics of Singapore
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Singapore" title="Human rights in Singapore">
       Human rights in Singapore
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Singapore" title="Administrative divisions of Singapore">
       Administrative divisions of Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ParliamentHouse-Singapore-20071120.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/ParliamentHouse-Singapore-20071120.jpg/220px-ParliamentHouse-Singapore-20071120.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/ParliamentHouse-Singapore-20071120.jpg/330px-ParliamentHouse-Singapore-20071120.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/ParliamentHouse-Singapore-20071120.jpg/440px-ParliamentHouse-Singapore-20071120.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ParliamentHouse-Singapore-20071120.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Singapore's
        <a href="/wiki/Parliament_House,_Singapore" title="Parliament House, Singapore">
         Parliament House
        </a>
        , beside the
        <a href="/wiki/Singapore_River" title="Singapore River">
         Singapore River
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Singapore is a parliamentary republic with a
      <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">
       Westminster system
      </a>
      of unicameral parliamentary government representing
      <a href="/wiki/Constituencies_of_Singapore" title="Constituencies of Singapore">
       constituencies
      </a>
      . The country's
      <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Singapore" title="Constitution of Singapore">
       constitution
      </a>
      establishes a
      <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy_in_Singapore" title="Representative democracy in Singapore">
       representative democracy
      </a>
      as the political system.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_34-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-34">
        [34]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Executive power rests with the
      <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Singapore" title="Cabinet of Singapore">
       Cabinet of Singapore
      </a>
      , led by the Prime Minister and, to a much lesser extent, the President.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Law_27-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Law-27">
        [27]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The President is elected through a popular vote, and has
      <a href="/wiki/Veto" title="Veto">
       veto
      </a>
      powers over a specific set of executive decisions, such as the use of the national reserves and the appointment of judges, but otherwise occupies a largely ceremonial post.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
       <a href="#cite_note-35">
        [35]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Parliament serves as the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legislative_branch" title="Legislative branch">
       legislative branch
      </a>
      of the government.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Law_27-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Law-27">
        [27]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Members_of_Parliament" title="Members of Parliament">
       Members of Parliament
      </a>
      (MPs) consist of elected, non-constituency and nominated members. Elected MPs are voted into the Parliament on a "
      <a href="/wiki/First-past-the-post_voting" title="First-past-the-post voting">
       first-past-the-post
      </a>
      " (plurality) basis and represent either single-member or
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Group_representation_constituencies" title="Group representation constituencies">
       group representation constituencies
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parliament.gov.sg_36-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-parliament.gov.sg-36">
        [36]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The People's Action Party has won control of Parliament with large majorities in every election since self-governance was secured in 1959.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_37-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-37">
        [37]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Although the elections are clean, there is no independent electoral authority and the government has strong influence on the media.
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">
       Freedom House
      </a>
      ranks Singapore as "partly free" in its
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">
        Freedom in the World
       </a>
      </i>
      report,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_37-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-37">
        [37]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">
        The Economist
       </a>
      </i>
      ranks Singapore as a "flawed democracy", the second best rank of four, in its "
      <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">
       Democracy Index
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
       <a href="#cite_note-38">
        [38]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
       <a href="#cite_note-39">
        [39]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 2011 Parliamentary elections, the opposition, led by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_of_Singapore" title="Workers' Party of Singapore">
       Workers' Party
      </a>
      , increased its representation to seven elected MPs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
       <a href="#cite_note-40">
        [40]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 2015 elections, PAP scored a landslide victory, winning 83 of 89 seats contested, with 70% of popular votes.
      <a href="/wiki/Gallup_(company)" title="Gallup (company)">
       Gallup
      </a>
      polls reported 84% of residents in Singapore expressed confidence in the government, one of the highest ratings in the world, and 85% in its judicial systems and courts.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
       <a href="#cite_note-41">
        [41]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary.2C_secondary_and_tertiary_sources" title="Wikipedia:No original research">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable secondary sources. (October 2016)">
          non-primary source needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Singapore's governance model eschews
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Populist" title="Populist">
       populist
      </a>
      politics, focusing on the nation's long-term interest, and is known to be clean, effective and pragmatic. As a small nation highly dependent on external trade, it is vulnerable to geo-politics and global economics. It places great emphasis on security and stability of the region in its foreign policies, and applies global best practices to ensure the nation's attractiveness as an investment destination and business hub.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lky-7prin_32-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-lky-7prin-32">
        [32]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
       <a href="#cite_note-42">
        [42]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sg-unicorn_43-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-sg-unicorn-43">
        [43]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Supreme_Court_of_Singapore_at_night_(HDR)_-_20071115.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2600" data-file-width="3888" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Supreme_Court_of_Singapore_at_night_%28HDR%29_-_20071115.jpg/220px-Supreme_Court_of_Singapore_at_night_%28HDR%29_-_20071115.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Supreme_Court_of_Singapore_at_night_%28HDR%29_-_20071115.jpg/330px-Supreme_Court_of_Singapore_at_night_%28HDR%29_-_20071115.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Supreme_Court_of_Singapore_at_night_%28HDR%29_-_20071115.jpg/440px-Supreme_Court_of_Singapore_at_night_%28HDR%29_-_20071115.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Supreme_Court_of_Singapore_at_night_(HDR)_-_20071115.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        New and old
        <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Singapore" title="Supreme Court of Singapore">
         Supreme Court
        </a>
        buildings. The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Court_of_Appeal" title="Court of Appeal">
         Court of Appeal
        </a>
        occupies the 'disc' atop, representing the highest level of
        <a href="/wiki/Justice" title="Justice">
         justice
        </a>
        , and a modern interpretation of the
        <a href="/wiki/Dome" title="Dome">
         dome
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Singapore" title="Law of Singapore">
       legal system of Singapore
      </a>
      is based on
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_common_law" title="English common law">
       English common law
      </a>
      , but with substantial local differences.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trial_by_jury" title="Trial by jury">
       Trial by jury
      </a>
      was abolished in 1970 so that judicial decisions would rest entirely in the hands of appointed judges.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
       <a href="#cite_note-44">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Singapore has penalties that include
      <a href="/wiki/Judicial_corporal_punishment" title="Judicial corporal punishment">
       judicial corporal punishment
      </a>
      in the form of
      <a href="/wiki/Caning_in_Singapore" title="Caning in Singapore">
       caning
      </a>
      , which may be imposed for such offences as rape, rioting, vandalism, and certain immigration offences.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
       <a href="#cite_note-45">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
       <a href="#cite_note-46">
        [46]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There is a mandatory
      <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Singapore" title="Capital punishment in Singapore">
       death penalty
      </a>
      for murder, as well as for certain aggravated drug-trafficking and firearms offences.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
       <a href="#cite_note-47">
        [47]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">
       Amnesty International
      </a>
      has said that some legal provisions of the Singapore system conflict with the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty, and that Singapore has "... possibly the highest execution rate in the world relative to its population".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-amnesty_48-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-amnesty-48">
        [48]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The government has disputed Amnesty's claims.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-response_49-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-response-49">
        [49]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In a 2008 survey of international business executives, Singapore received the top ranking with regard to judicial system quality in Asia.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
       <a href="#cite_note-50">
        [50]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Singapore has been consistently rated among the least corrupt countries in the world by
      <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">
       Transparency International
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
       <a href="#cite_note-51">
        [51]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2011, the
      <a href="/wiki/World_Justice_Project" title="World Justice Project">
       World Justice Project
      </a>
      's
      <i>
       Rule of Law Index
      </i>
      ranked Singapore among the top countries surveyed with regard to "order and security", "absence of corruption", and "effective criminal justice". However, the country received a much lower ranking for "
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">
       freedom of speech
      </a>
      " and "
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly" title="Freedom of assembly">
       freedom of assembly
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
       <a href="#cite_note-52">
        [52]
       </a>
      </sup>
      All public gatherings of five or more people require police permits, and protests may legally be held only at the
      <a href="/wiki/Speakers%27_Corner,_Singapore" title="Speakers' Corner, Singapore">
       Speakers' Corner
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
       <a href="#cite_note-53">
        [53]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">
       Foreign relations
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Singapore" title="Foreign relations of Singapore">
       Foreign relations of Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lee_Kuan_Yew_Cohen.jpg">
        <img alt="Ambassador to the USA Chan Heng Chee, Lee Kuan Yew, and US Secretary of Defense William Cohen in a room" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1970" data-file-width="2670" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Lee_Kuan_Yew_Cohen.jpg/220px-Lee_Kuan_Yew_Cohen.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Lee_Kuan_Yew_Cohen.jpg/330px-Lee_Kuan_Yew_Cohen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Lee_Kuan_Yew_Cohen.jpg/440px-Lee_Kuan_Yew_Cohen.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lee_Kuan_Yew_Cohen.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Then
        <a href="/wiki/Senior_Minister" title="Senior Minister">
         Senior Minister
        </a>
        Lee Kuan Yew and Ambassador to the US
        <a href="/wiki/Chan_Heng_Chee" title="Chan Heng Chee">
         Chan Heng Chee
        </a>
        , met with US Secretary of Defense
        <a href="/wiki/William_Cohen" title="William Cohen">
         William Cohen
        </a>
        during a visit in 2000.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Singapore's foreign policy is aimed at maintaining security in Southeast Asia and surrounding territories. An underlying principle is political and economic stability in the region.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govt.nz_54-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-govt.nz-54">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It has diplomatic relations with more than 180 sovereign states.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
       <a href="#cite_note-55">
        [55]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since 2002, it has hosted the annual inter-government security forum
      <a href="/wiki/Shangri-La_Dialogue" title="Shangri-La Dialogue">
       Shangri-La Dialogue
      </a>
      , by the
      <a href="/wiki/International_Institute_for_Strategic_Studies" title="International Institute for Strategic Studies">
       International Institute for Strategic Studies
      </a>
      , attended by ministers and defence officials from the Asia-Pacific and Europe. The high-level dialogue has had influence on confrontational issues, such as territorial disputes in the East and South China seas, together with discussions about global security and terrorism.
     </p>
     <p>
      As one of the five founding members of ASEAN,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
       <a href="#cite_note-56">
        [56]
       </a>
      </sup>
      it is a strong supporter of the
      <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Free_Trade_Area" title="ASEAN Free Trade Area">
       ASEAN Free Trade Area
      </a>
      (AFTA) and the ASEAN Investment Area, because Singapore's economy is closely linked to that of the region as a whole. Former Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong proposed the formation of an
      <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations#Economic_community" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">
       ASEAN Economic Community
      </a>
      , a step beyond the current AFTA, bringing it closer to a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Common_market" title="Common market">
       common market
      </a>
      . This was agreed to in 2007 for implementation by 2015. Other regional organisations are important to Singapore, and it is the host of the APEC Secretariat. Singapore maintains membership in other regional organisations, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Asia%E2%80%93Europe_Meeting" title="Asia–Europe Meeting">
       Asia–Europe Meeting
      </a>
      , the Forum for East Asia-Latin American Cooperation, the
      <a href="/wiki/Asian_Network_of_Major_Cities_21" title="Asian Network of Major Cities 21">
       Asian Network of Major Cities 21
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">
       East Asia Summit
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govt.nz_54-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-govt.nz-54">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It is also a member of the Non-Aligned Movement
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
       <a href="#cite_note-57">
        [57]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the Commonwealth.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
       <a href="#cite_note-58">
        [58]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_at_ASEAN_Summit_2012.jpg">
        <img alt="Barack Obama attends the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) meeting at ASEAN Summit 2012" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2731" data-file-width="4096" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Barack_Obama_at_ASEAN_Summit_2012.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_at_ASEAN_Summit_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Barack_Obama_at_ASEAN_Summit_2012.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_at_ASEAN_Summit_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Barack_Obama_at_ASEAN_Summit_2012.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_at_ASEAN_Summit_2012.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_at_ASEAN_Summit_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Prime Minister
        <a href="/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong" title="Lee Hsien Loong">
         Lee Hsien Loong
        </a>
        and US President
        <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
         Barack Obama
        </a>
        attended the
        <a href="/wiki/Trans-Pacific_Partnership" title="Trans-Pacific Partnership">
         Trans-Pacific Partnership
        </a>
        (TPP) meeting at
        <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Summit" title="ASEAN Summit">
         ASEAN Summit
        </a>
        2012.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In general, bilateral relations with other ASEAN members are strong; however, disagreements have arisen,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govt.nz_54-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-govt.nz-54">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and relations with neighbouring Malaysia and
      <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">
       Indonesia
      </a>
      have sometimes been strained.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rocky_59-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Rocky-59">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Malaysia and Singapore have clashed over the delivery of
      <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">
       fresh water
      </a>
      to Singapore,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Disputes_60-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Disputes-60">
        [60]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and access by the Singapore Armed Forces to Malaysian airspace.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rocky_59-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Rocky-59">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Border issues exist with Malaysia and Indonesia, and both have banned the sale of marine sand to Singapore over disputes about Singapore's land reclamation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        [61]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Some previous disputes have been resolved by the
      <a href="/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice" title="International Court of Justice">
       International Court of Justice
      </a>
      . Piracy in the
      <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Malacca" title="Strait of Malacca">
       Strait of Malacca
      </a>
      has been a cause of concern for all three countries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Disputes_60-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Disputes-60">
        [60]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Close economic ties exist with
      <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">
       Brunei
      </a>
      , and the two share a pegged currency value.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        [62]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The first diplomatic contact with
      <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
       China
      </a>
      was made in the 1970s, with full diplomatic relations established in the 1990s. Since then the two countries have been major players in strengthening the ASEAN–China relationship.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
       <a href="#cite_note-63">
        [63]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Singapore and the
      <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
       United States
      </a>
      share a long-standing close relationship, in particular in defence, the economy, health, and education. The United States was Singapore's third largest trading partner in 2010, behind
      <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
       China
      </a>
      (2nd) and Malaysia (1st).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
       <a href="#cite_note-64">
        [64]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The two countries have a free-trade agreement, and Singapore views its relationship with the United States as an important counterbalance to China's influence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-diplomat20120214_65-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-diplomat20120214-65">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A Strategic Framework Agreement between the two, signed in 2005, formalises security and defence co-operation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
       <a href="#cite_note-66">
        [66]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Singapore has pushed regional counter-terrorism initiatives, with a strong resolve to deal with terrorists inside its borders. To this end it has given support to the US-led coalition to fight terrorism, with bilateral co-operation in counter-terrorism and counter-proliferation initiatives, and joint military exercises.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govt.nz_54-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-govt.nz-54">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
       Military
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces" title="Singapore Armed Forces">
       Singapore Armed Forces
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The Singaporean military is arguably the most technologically advanced in Southeast Asia.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
       <a href="#cite_note-67">
        [67]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It comprises the
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Army" title="Singapore Army">
       Singapore Army
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Singapore_Navy" title="Republic of Singapore Navy">
       Republic of Singapore Navy
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Singapore_Air_Force" title="Republic of Singapore Air Force">
       Republic of Singapore Air Force
      </a>
      . It is seen as the guarantor of the country's independence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
       <a href="#cite_note-68">
        [68]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The nation's philosophy of defence is one of diplomacy and deterrence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mindef18Feb2008_69-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mindef18Feb2008-69">
        [69]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This principle translates into the culture, involving all citizens in the country's defence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MindefApr2005_70-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MindefApr2005-70">
        [70]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The government spends 4.9% of the country's GDP on the military, and one out of every four dollars of government spending is spent on defence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
       <a href="#cite_note-71">
        [71]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Boeing_F-15SG_Strike_Eagle,_Singapore_-_Air_Force_JP7096555.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1068" data-file-width="1600" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Boeing_F-15SG_Strike_Eagle%2C_Singapore_-_Air_Force_JP7096555.jpg/220px-Boeing_F-15SG_Strike_Eagle%2C_Singapore_-_Air_Force_JP7096555.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Boeing_F-15SG_Strike_Eagle%2C_Singapore_-_Air_Force_JP7096555.jpg/330px-Boeing_F-15SG_Strike_Eagle%2C_Singapore_-_Air_Force_JP7096555.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Boeing_F-15SG_Strike_Eagle%2C_Singapore_-_Air_Force_JP7096555.jpg/440px-Boeing_F-15SG_Strike_Eagle%2C_Singapore_-_Air_Force_JP7096555.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Boeing_F-15SG_Strike_Eagle,_Singapore_-_Air_Force_JP7096555.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singapore_Air_Force" title="Singapore Air Force">
         Singapore Air Force
        </a>
        's
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-15SG" title="F-15SG">
         F-15SG
        </a>
        are
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Strike_Eagle" title="Strike Eagle">
          Strike Eagle
         </a>
        </i>
        variants (24 units). Pilots also train in
        <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">
         Australia
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">
         France
        </a>
        and the
        <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
         United States
        </a>
        due to severe airspace constraints.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      After its independence, Singapore had two
      <a href="/wiki/Infantry" title="Infantry">
       infantry
      </a>
      regiments commanded by British officers. This force was considered too small to provide effective security for the new country, so development of its military forces became a priority.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cs.uwec_72-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-cs.uwec-72">
        [72]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Britain pulled its military out of Singapore in October 1971, leaving behind only a small British, Australian and New Zealand force as a token military presence. The last British soldier left Singapore in March 1976. New Zealand troops were the last to leave, in 1989.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        [73]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A great deal of initial support came from
      <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">
       Israel
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cs.uwec_72-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-cs.uwec-72">
        [72]
       </a>
      </sup>
      a country that is not recognised by the neighbouring
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic" title="Islamic">
       Muslim-majority
      </a>
      nations of Malaysia, Indonesia, or Brunei.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        [74]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        [75]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
       <a href="#cite_note-76">
        [76]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The main fear after independence was an invasion by Malaysia.
      <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">
       Israeli Defense Force
      </a>
      (IDF) commanders were tasked with creating the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) from scratch, and Israeli instructors were brought in to train Singaporean soldiers. Military courses were conducted according to the IDF's format, and Singapore adopted a system of conscription and reserve service based on
      <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Israel" title="Conscription in Israel">
       the Israeli
      </a>
      model.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cs.uwec_72-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-cs.uwec-72">
        [72]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Singapore still maintains strong security ties with Israel and is one of the biggest buyers of Israeli arms and weapons systems.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        [77]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MATADOR_(weapon)" title="MATADOR (weapon)">
       MATADOR
      </a>
      is one example of recent Singaporean–Israeli collaboration.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
       <a href="#cite_note-78">
        [78]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The SAF is being developed to respond to a wide range of issues, in both conventional and unconventional warfare. The
      <a href="/wiki/Defence_Science_and_Technology_Agency" title="Defence Science and Technology Agency">
       Defence Science and Technology Agency
      </a>
      is responsible for procuring resources for the military.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mindef18Feb2008_69-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mindef18Feb2008-69">
        [69]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The geographic restrictions of Singapore mean that the SAF must plan to fully repulse an attack, as they can not fall back and re-group. The small size of the population has also affected the way the SAF has been designed, with a small active force but a large number of reserves.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MindefApr2005_70-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-MindefApr2005-70">
        [70]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Singapore has
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Singapore" title="Conscription in Singapore">
       conscription
      </a>
      for all able-bodied males at age 18, except those with a criminal record or who can prove that their loss would bring hardship to their families. Males who have yet to complete pre-university education or are awarded the
      <a href="/wiki/Public_Service_Commission_(Singapore)" title="Public Service Commission (Singapore)">
       Public Service Commission
      </a>
      scholarship can opt to defer their draft. Though not required to perform military service, the number of women in the SAF has been increasing: since 1989 they have been allowed to fill military vocations formerly reserved for men. Before induction into a specific branch of the armed forces, recruits undergo at least 9 weeks of basic military training.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-country-data_79-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-country-data-79">
        [79]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_100716-N-0995C-155_The_Singapore_navy_guided-missile_frigate_RSS_Steadfast_(FFG_70)_and_the_corvette_RSS_Vigilance_(90)_are_underway_during_Cooperation_Afloat_Readiness_and_Training_(CARAT)_Singapore_2010.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="2100" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/US_Navy_100716-N-0995C-155_The_Singapore_navy_guided-missile_frigate_RSS_Steadfast_%28FFG_70%29_and_the_corvette_RSS_Vigilance_%2890%29_are_underway_during_Cooperation_Afloat_Readiness_and_Training_%28CARAT%29_Singapore_2010.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/US_Navy_100716-N-0995C-155_The_Singapore_navy_guided-missile_frigate_RSS_Steadfast_%28FFG_70%29_and_the_corvette_RSS_Vigilance_%2890%29_are_underway_during_Cooperation_Afloat_Readiness_and_Training_%28CARAT%29_Singapore_2010.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/US_Navy_100716-N-0995C-155_The_Singapore_navy_guided-missile_frigate_RSS_Steadfast_%28FFG_70%29_and_the_corvette_RSS_Vigilance_%2890%29_are_underway_during_Cooperation_Afloat_Readiness_and_Training_%28CARAT%29_Singapore_2010.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_100716-N-0995C-155_The_Singapore_navy_guided-missile_frigate_RSS_Steadfast_(FFG_70)_and_the_corvette_RSS_Vigilance_(90)_are_underway_during_Cooperation_Afloat_Readiness_and_Training_(CARAT)_Singapore_2010.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Republic of Singapore Navy's
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Formidable_class_frigate" title="Formidable class frigate">
         RSS
         <i>
          Steadfast
         </i>
        </a>
        and
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victory_class_corvette" title="Victory class corvette">
         RSS
         <i>
          Vigilance
         </i>
        </a>
        sailing line-abreast during
        <a href="/wiki/Cooperation_Afloat_Readiness_and_Training" title="Cooperation Afloat Readiness and Training">
         CARAT Singapore 2010
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Because of the scarcity of open land on the main island, training involving activities such as live firing and
      <a href="/wiki/Amphibious_warfare" title="Amphibious warfare">
       amphibious warfare
      </a>
      is often carried out on smaller islands, typically barred to civilian access. This also avoids risk to the main island and the city. However, large-scale drills are considered too dangerous to be performed in the area, and since 1975 have been performed in Taiwan.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-country-data_79-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-country-data-79">
        [79]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Training is also held in about a dozen other countries. In general, military exercises are held with foreign forces once or twice per week.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MindefApr2005_70-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-MindefApr2005-70">
        [70]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Due to airspace and land constraints, the Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) maintains a number of overseas bases in
      <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">
       Australia
      </a>
      , the United States, and France. The RSAF's 130 Squadron is based in
      <a href="/wiki/RAAF_Base_Pearce" title="RAAF Base Pearce">
       RAAF Base Pearce
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Western_Australia" title="Western Australia">
       Western Australia
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
       <a href="#cite_note-80">
        [80]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and its
      <a href="/wiki/126_Squadron,_Republic_of_Singapore_Air_Force" title="126 Squadron, Republic of Singapore Air Force">
       126 Squadron
      </a>
      is based in the
      <a href="/wiki/Oakey_Army_Aviation_Centre" title="Oakey Army Aviation Centre">
       Oakey Army Aviation Centre
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Queensland" title="Queensland">
       Queensland
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
       <a href="#cite_note-81">
        [81]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The RSAF has one squadron—the 150 Squadron—based in
      <a href="/wiki/Cazaux" title="Cazaux">
       Cazaux
      </a>
      Air Base in southern
      <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">
       France
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
       <a href="#cite_note-82">
        [82]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
       <a href="#cite_note-83">
        [83]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The RSAF also has a few overseas detachments in the United States, in
      <a href="/wiki/San_Diego" title="San Diego">
       San Diego
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">
       California
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Marana,_Arizona" title="Marana, Arizona">
       Marana, Arizona
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Grand_Prairie,_Texas" title="Grand Prairie, Texas">
       Grand Prairie, Texas
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Luke_Air_Force_Base" title="Luke Air Force Base">
       Luke Air Force Base
      </a>
      , among others.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
       <a href="#cite_note-84">
        [84]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
       <a href="#cite_note-85">
        [85]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The SAF has sent forces to assist in operations outside the country, in areas such as
      <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">
       Iraq
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
       <a href="#cite_note-86">
        [86]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">
       Afghanistan
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
       <a href="#cite_note-87">
        [87]
       </a>
      </sup>
      in both military and civilian roles. In the region, it has helped stabilise
      <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">
       East Timor
      </a>
      and has provided aid to
      <a href="/wiki/Aceh" title="Aceh">
       Aceh
      </a>
      in Indonesia following the
      <a href="/wiki/2004_Indian_Ocean_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami">
       2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami
      </a>
      . In 2014, the RSN deployed two ships, the RSS
      <i>
       Resolute
      </i>
      and the
      <i>
       Tenacious
      </i>
      to the
      <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Aden" title="Gulf of Aden">
       Gulf of Aden
      </a>
      to aid in counter
      <a href="/wiki/Piracy" title="Piracy">
       piracy
      </a>
      efforts as part of
      <a href="/wiki/Combined_Task_Force_151" title="Combined Task Force 151">
       Task Force 151
      </a>
      . The SAF also helped in relief efforts during
      <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">
       Hurricane Katrina
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Typhoon_Haiyan" title="Typhoon Haiyan">
       Typhoon Haiyan
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
       <a href="#cite_note-88">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Singapore is part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Five_Power_Defence_Arrangements" title="Five Power Defence Arrangements">
       Five Power Defence Arrangements
      </a>
      , a military alliance with Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MindefApr2005_70-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-MindefApr2005-70">
        [70]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
       Geography
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Singapore" title="Geography of Singapore">
       Geography of Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:329px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CIA_World_Factbook_map_of_Singapore_(English).png">
        <img alt="Map showing Singapore island and the territories belonging to Singapore and its neighbours" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="350" data-file-width="327" height="350" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/07/CIA_World_Factbook_map_of_Singapore_%28English%29.png" width="327"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CIA_World_Factbook_map_of_Singapore_(English).png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        An outline of Singapore and the surrounding islands and waterways.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Singapore consists of
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Singapore" title="List of islands of Singapore">
       63 islands
      </a>
      , including the main island,
      <a href="/wiki/Pulau_Ujong" title="Pulau Ujong">
       Pulau Ujong
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
       <a href="#cite_note-89">
        [89]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are two man-made connections to Johor, Malaysia: the
      <a href="/wiki/Johor%E2%80%93Singapore_Causeway" title="Johor–Singapore Causeway">
       Johor–Singapore Causeway
      </a>
      in the north and the
      <a href="/wiki/Malaysia%E2%80%93Singapore_Second_Link" title="Malaysia–Singapore Second Link">
       Tuas Second Link
      </a>
      in the west.
      <a href="/wiki/Jurong_Island" title="Jurong Island">
       Jurong Island
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Pulau_Tekong" title="Pulau Tekong">
       Pulau Tekong
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Pulau_Ubin" title="Pulau Ubin">
       Pulau Ubin
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sentosa" title="Sentosa">
       Sentosa
      </a>
      are the largest of Singapore's smaller islands. The highest natural point is
      <a href="/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Hill" title="Bukit Timah Hill">
       Bukit Timah Hill
      </a>
      at 163.63 m (537 ft).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
       <a href="#cite_note-90">
        [90]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Ongoing
      <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">
       land reclamation
      </a>
      projects have increased Singapore's land area from 581.5 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      (224.5 sq mi) in the 1960s to 719.1 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      (277.6 sq mi) in 2015, an increase of some 23% (130 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat2015pop.26land_9-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-singstat2015pop.26land-9">
        [9]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
       <a href="#cite_note-91">
        [91]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The country is projected to grow by another 100 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      (40 sq mi) by 2030.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
       <a href="#cite_note-92">
        [92]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Some projects involve merging smaller islands through land reclamation to form larger, more functional islands, as has been done with Jurong Island.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-earthshots.usgs.gov_93-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-earthshots.usgs.gov-93">
        [93]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Nearly 10% of Singapore's land has been set aside for parks and
      <a href="/wiki/Nature_reserve" title="Nature reserve">
       nature reserves
      </a>
      . The network of nature reserves, parks,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Park_connector" title="Park connector">
       park connectors
      </a>
      , nature ways, tree-lined roads and other natural areas have enhanced the sense of green space in the city.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        [94]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This is a result of five decades of greening efforts, which began in 1963, when Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew launched Singapore's first tree-planting campaign by planting a mempat tree (
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Cratoxylum_formosum" title="Cratoxylum formosum">
        Cratoxylum formosum
       </a>
      </i>
      ). The aim was to soften the harshness of urbanisation and improve the quality of life.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
       <a href="#cite_note-95">
        [95]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This initiative continued into the 1970s and 1980s under the Parks and Recreation Department (PRD), renamed the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Parks_Board" title="National Parks Board">
       National Parks Board
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Abbreviation" title="Abbreviation">
       abbreviation
      </a>
      : NParks) in July 1996.
     </p>
     <p>
      Due to these efforts, Singapore was ranked fourth in the 2014
      <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index" title="Environmental Performance Index">
       Environmental Performance Index
      </a>
      , which measures the effectiveness of state policies for environmental sustainability.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
       <a href="#cite_note-96">
        [96]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
       Climate
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Singapore has a
      <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest_climate" title="Tropical rainforest climate">
       tropical rainforest climate
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">
       Köppen
      </a>
      :
      <i>
       Af
      </i>
      ) with no distinctive seasons, uniform temperature and pressure, high humidity, and abundant rainfall. Temperatures usually range from 22 to 35 °C (72 to 95 °F).
      <a href="/wiki/Relative_humidity" title="Relative humidity">
       Relative humidity
      </a>
      averages around 79% in the morning and 73% in the afternoon.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
       <a href="#cite_note-97">
        [97]
       </a>
      </sup>
      April and May are the hottest months, with the wetter
      <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">
       monsoon
      </a>
      season from November to January.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
       <a href="#cite_note-98">
        [98]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      From July to October, there is often
      <a href="/wiki/Haze" title="Haze">
       haze
      </a>
      caused by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bush_fire" title="Bush fire">
       bush fires
      </a>
      in neighbouring Indonesia, usually from the island of Sumatra.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
       <a href="#cite_note-99">
        [99]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although Singapore does not observe
      <a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">
       daylight saving time
      </a>
      (DST), it follows the GMT+8 time zone, one hour ahead of the typical zone for its geographical location.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
       <a href="#cite_note-100">
        [100]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <br/>
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable collapsible" style="width:90%; text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height: 1.2em; margin:auto;">

       </th>

       </th>
       <th>

       </th>
      </tr>

       </td>

        <br/>

       </td>
       <td style="background: #FF2A00; color:#000000;">
        35.4
        <br/>
        (95.7)
       </td>
       <td style="background: #FF2C00; color:#000000;">
        35.0
        <br/>
        (95)
       </td>
       <td style="background: #FF3300; color:#000000;">

        <br/>
        (93.2)
       </td>
       <td style="background: #FF3200; color:#000000;">

        <br/>
        (93.6)
       </td>
       <td style="background: #FF3100; color:#000000;">
        34.3
        <br/>
        (93.7)
       </td>
       <td style="background: #FF2F00; color:#000000;">
        34.6
        <br/>
        (94.3)
       </td>
       <td style="background: #FF3200; color:#000000;">
        34.2
        <br/>
        (93.6)
       </td>
       <td style="background: #FF3500; color:#000000;">
        33.8
        <br/>
        (92.8)
       </td>

       </td>
      </tr>
