      Singaporeans are mostly
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bilingual" title="Bilingual">
       bilingual
      </a>
      , with
      <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
       English
      </a>
      as their common language and usually the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother-tongue" title="Mother-tongue">
       mother-tongue
      </a>
      as a second language taught in schools, in order to preserve each individual's ethnic identity and values. The official languages amongst Singaporeans are English (80% literacy), Mandarin (65% literacy), Malay (17% literacy), and Tamil (4% literacy).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010censuspercentage_198-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-2010censuspercentage-198">
        [197]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
       <a href="#cite_note-211">
        [210]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_English" title="Singapore English">
       Singapore English
      </a>
      is based on
      <a href="/wiki/British_English" title="British English">
       British English
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
       <a href="#cite_note-212">
        [211]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and forms of English spoken in Singapore range from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singapore_Standard_English" title="Singapore Standard English">
       Standard Singapore English
      </a>
      to a colloquial form known as "
      <a href="/wiki/Singlish" title="Singlish">
       Singlish
      </a>
      ". Singlish is discouraged by the government.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
       <a href="#cite_note-213">
        [212]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Teochew_Building,_Mar_06.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1200" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Teochew_Building%2C_Mar_06.JPG/150px-Teochew_Building%2C_Mar_06.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Teochew_Building%2C_Mar_06.JPG/225px-Teochew_Building%2C_Mar_06.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Teochew_Building%2C_Mar_06.JPG/300px-Teochew_Building%2C_Mar_06.JPG 2x" width="150"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Teochew_Building,_Mar_06.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Clan associations played an important role in preserving ethnic dialects and cultural practices in the early years.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">
       Mandarin
      </a>
      is the language that is spoken as the native tongue by the greatest number of Singaporeans, half of them.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat1_210-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-singstat1-210">
        [209]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Singaporean_Mandarin" title="Singaporean Mandarin">
       Singaporean Mandarin
      </a>
      is the most common version of Chinese in the country,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_214-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BBC-214">
        [213]
       </a>
      </sup>
      with 1.2 million using it as their home language. Nearly half a million speak other
      <a href="/wiki/Varieties_of_Chinese" title="Varieties of Chinese">
       varieties of Chinese
      </a>
      , mainly
      <a href="/wiki/Hokkien" title="Hokkien">
       Hokkien
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Teochew_dialect" title="Teochew dialect">
       Teochew
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Cantonese" title="Cantonese">
       Cantonese
      </a>
      , as their home language, although the use of these is declining in favour of Mandarin and English.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat.gov.sg_215-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-singstat.gov.sg-215">
        [214]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">
       Malay
      </a>
      was chosen as a national language by the Singaporean government after independence from Britain in the 1960s to avoid friction with Singapore's Malay-speaking neighbours—Malaysia and Indonesia.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fromthirdworldtofirst_216-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-fromthirdworldtofirst-216">
        [215]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It has a symbolic, rather than functional purpose.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statutes.agc.gov.sg_203-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-statutes.agc.gov.sg-203">
        [202]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
       <a href="#cite_note-217">
        [216]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
       <a href="#cite_note-218">
        [217]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It is used in the national anthem "Majulah Singapura",
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
       <a href="#cite_note-219">
        [218]
       </a>
      </sup>
      in citations of
      <a href="/wiki/Singaporean_orders_and_decorations" title="Singaporean orders and decorations">
       Singaporean orders and decorations
      </a>
      , and in military commands. In general, Malay is spoken mainly within the Singaporean Malay community, with only 17% of all Singaporeans literate in Malay
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
       <a href="#cite_note-220">
        [219]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and only 12% using it as their native language.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat1_210-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-singstat1-210">
        [209]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Around 100,000, or 3%, of Singaporeans speak Tamil as their native language.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat1_210-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-singstat1-210">
        [209]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Tamil has official status in Singapore and there have been no attempts to discourage the use of other Indian languages.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
       <a href="#cite_note-221">
        [220]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Employment">
       Employment
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Employment_in_Singapore" title="Employment in Singapore">
       Employment in Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Singapore traditionally has one of the lowest
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_unemployment_rate" title="List of countries by unemployment rate">
       unemployment rates
      </a>
      among developed countries. The unemployment rate did not exceed 4% from 2005 to 2014, hitting highs of 3.1% in 2005 and 3% during the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late-2000s_financial_crisis" title="Late-2000s financial crisis">
       2009 global financial crisis
      </a>
      ; it fell to 1.8% in the first quarter of 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
       <a href="#cite_note-222">
        [221]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The government provides numerous assistance programmes to the homeless and needy through the
      <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Social_and_Family_Development" title="Ministry of Social and Family Development">
       Ministry of Social and Family Development
      </a>
      , so acute poverty is rare. Some of the programmes include providing between SGD400 and SGD1000 per month to needy households, providing free medical care at government hospitals, and paying for children's school fees.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
       <a href="#cite_note-223">
        [222]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
       <a href="#cite_note-224">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
       <a href="#cite_note-225">
        [224]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Singapore government also provides numerous benefits to its citizenry, including: free money to encourage residents to exercise in public gyms,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
       <a href="#cite_note-226">
        [225]
       </a>
      </sup>
      up to $166,000 worth of
      <a href="/wiki/Baby_bonus" title="Baby bonus">
       baby bonus
      </a>
      benefits for each baby born to a citizen,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
       <a href="#cite_note-227">
        [226]
       </a>
      </sup>
      heavily subsidised healthcare, money to help the disabled, cheap laptops for poor students,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
       <a href="#cite_note-228">
        [227]
       </a>
      </sup>
      rebates for numerous areas such as public transport,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
       <a href="#cite_note-229">
        [228]
       </a>
      </sup>
      utility bills and more.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
       <a href="#cite_note-230">
        [229]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
       <a href="#cite_note-231">
        [230]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Although it has been recognised that foreign workers are crucial to the country's economy, the government is considering capping these workers,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
       <a href="#cite_note-232">
        [231]
       </a>
      </sup>
      as foreign workers make up 80% of the construction industry and up to 50% of the service industry.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
       <a href="#cite_note-233">
        [232]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
       <a href="#cite_note-234">
        [233]
       </a>
      </sup>
      To keep an effective tap on the issue of immigration and to also attract foreign talents at the same time, the Ministry of Manpower (MoM) issues employment pass under three categories viz: P1 Employment Pass for those individuals with monthly earning of $8,000 and up, P2 Employment Pass for individuals with monthly earning of $4,500–7,999 and Q1 Employment Pass individuals with at least a monthly earning of $3,000.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
       <a href="#cite_note-235">
        [234]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; width:100%; max-width:1708px;">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="">
       <div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Panoramic_view_of_the_Central_Business_District,_Singapore,_and_ships_-_20100712.jpg" title="A view of the cityscape and anchored ships from Singapore's Eastern Anchorage off the East Coast Park">
         <img alt="" data-file-height="1806" data-file-width="20414" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Panoramic_view_of_the_Central_Business_District%2C_Singapore%2C_and_ships_-_20100712.jpg/1700px-Panoramic_view_of_the_Central_Business_District%2C_Singapore%2C_and_ships_-_20100712.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Panoramic_view_of_the_Central_Business_District%2C_Singapore%2C_and_ships_-_20100712.jpg/2550px-Panoramic_view_of_the_Central_Business_District%2C_Singapore%2C_and_ships_-_20100712.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Panoramic_view_of_the_Central_Business_District%2C_Singapore%2C_and_ships_-_20100712.jpg/3400px-Panoramic_view_of_the_Central_Business_District%2C_Singapore%2C_and_ships_-_20100712.jpg 2x" width="1700"/>
        </a>
       </div>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a href="/wiki/File:Panoramic_view_of_the_Central_Business_District,_Singapore,_and_ships_-_20100712.jpg" title="File:Panoramic view of the Central Business District, Singapore, and ships - 20100712.jpg">
         </a>
        </div>
        <center>
         A view of the cityscape and anchored ships from Singapore's Eastern Anchorage off the
         <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_Park" title="East Coast Park">
          East Coast Park
         </a>
        </center>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
       Education
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Singapore" title="Education in Singapore">
       Education in Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Management_University_17,_Aug_06.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG/220px-Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG/330px-Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG/440px-Singapore_Management_University_17%2C_Aug_06.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Singapore_Management_University_17,_Aug_06.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Management_University" title="Singapore Management University">
         Singapore Management University
        </a>
        is one of five
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Singapore" title="List of universities in Singapore">
         public universities in the city-state
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Education for primary, secondary, and tertiary levels is mostly supported by the state. All institutions, private and public, must be registered with the
      <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)" title="Ministry of Education (Singapore)">
       Ministry of Education
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
       <a href="#cite_note-236">
        [235]
       </a>
      </sup>
      English is the language of instruction in all public schools,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
       <a href="#cite_note-237">
        [236]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and all subjects are taught and examined in English except for the "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother_tongue" title="Mother tongue">
       mother tongue
      </a>
      " language paper.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
       <a href="#cite_note-238">
        [237]
       </a>
      </sup>
      While the term "mother tongue" in general refers to the first language internationally, in Singapore's education system, it is used to refer to the second language, as English is the first language.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
       <a href="#cite_note-239">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
       <a href="#cite_note-240">
        [239]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Students who have been abroad for a while, or who struggle with their "Mother Tongue" language, are allowed to take a simpler syllabus or drop the subject.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
       <a href="#cite_note-241">
        [240]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
       <a href="#cite_note-242">
        [241]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Education takes place in three stages: primary, secondary, and pre-university education. Only the primary level is compulsory. Students begin with six years of primary school, which is made up of a four-year foundation course and a two-year orientation stage. The curriculum is focused on the development of English, the mother tongue,
      <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">
       mathematics
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Natural_science" title="Natural science">
       science
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Primary_243-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Primary-243">
        [242]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
       <a href="#cite_note-244">
        [243]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Secondary school lasts from four to five years, and is divided between Special, Express, Normal (Academic), and Normal (Technical) streams in each school, depending on a student's ability level.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Secondary_245-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Secondary-245">
        [244]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The basic coursework breakdown is the same as in the primary level, although classes are much more specialised.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
       <a href="#cite_note-246">
        [245]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Pre-university education takes place over two to three years at senior schools, mostly called
      <a href="/wiki/Junior_college_(Singapore)" title="Junior college (Singapore)">
       Junior Colleges
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pre-university_247-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Pre-university-247">
        [246]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Some schools have a degree of freedom in their curriculum and are known as autonomous schools. These exist from the
      <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Singapore" title="Secondary education in Singapore">
       secondary education
      </a>
      level and up.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Secondary_245-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Secondary-245">
        [244]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hwa_Chong_Institution_Clock_Tower_Front_View.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Hwa_Chong_Institution_Clock_Tower_Front_View.JPG/220px-Hwa_Chong_Institution_Clock_Tower_Front_View.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Hwa_Chong_Institution_Clock_Tower_Front_View.JPG/330px-Hwa_Chong_Institution_Clock_Tower_Front_View.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Hwa_Chong_Institution_Clock_Tower_Front_View.JPG/440px-Hwa_Chong_Institution_Clock_Tower_Front_View.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hwa_Chong_Institution_Clock_Tower_Front_View.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Hwa_Chong_Institution" title="Hwa Chong Institution">
         Hwa Chong Institution
        </a>
        was the first Chinese institution of higher learning in
        <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">
         Southeast Asia
        </a>
        in 1919.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      National examinations are standardised across all schools, with a test taken after each stage. After the first six years of education, students take the
      <a href="/wiki/Primary_School_Leaving_Examination" title="Primary School Leaving Examination">
       Primary School Leaving Examination
      </a>
      (PSLE),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Primary_243-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Primary-243">
        [242]
       </a>
      </sup>
      which determines their placement at secondary school. At the end of the secondary stage,
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore-Cambridge_GCE_Ordinary_Level" title="Singapore-Cambridge GCE Ordinary Level">
       GCE "O"-Level
      </a>
      exams are taken; at the end of the following pre-university stage, the
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore-Cambridge_GCE_Advanced_Level" title="Singapore-Cambridge GCE Advanced Level">
       GCE "A"-Level
      </a>
      exams are taken. Of all non-student Singaporeans aged 15 and above, 18% have no education qualifications at all while 45% have the PSLE as their highest qualification; 15% have the GCE 'O' Level as their highest qualification and 14% have a degree.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chap2_248-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Chap2-248">
        [247]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Singaporean students consistently rank at or near the top of international education assessments:
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>
       In 2015, Singapore topped the
       <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        OECD's
       </a>
       global school performance rankings, based on 15-year-old students' average scores in mathematics and science across 76 countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
        <a href="#cite_note-249">
         [248]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
        <a href="#cite_note-250">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       Singaporean students were ranked first in the 2011
       <a href="/wiki/Trends_in_International_Mathematics_and_Science_Study" title="Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study">
        Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study
       </a>
       conducted by the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Association_for_the_Evaluation_of_Educational_Achievement" title="International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement">
        International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement
       </a>
       , and have been ranked in the top three every year since 1995.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
        <a href="#cite_note-251">
         [250]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
        <a href="#cite_note-252">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       Singapore fared best in the 2015
       <a href="/wiki/International_Baccalaureate" title="International Baccalaureate">
        International Baccalaureate
       </a>
       exams, taken in 107 countries, with more than half of the world's 81 perfect scorers and 98% passing rate.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
        <a href="#cite_note-253">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      Singapore has 6 public universities
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
       <a href="#cite_note-254">
        [253]
       </a>
      </sup>
      of which the
      <a href="/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore" title="National University of Singapore">
       National University of Singapore
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Nanyang_Technological_University" title="Nanyang Technological University">
       Nanyang Technological University
      </a>
      are often ranked among the top universities in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
       <a href="#cite_note-255">
        [254]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Health">
       Health
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Singapore" title="Healthcare in Singapore">
       Healthcare in Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bowyer_Block,_SGH.JPG">
        <img alt="The Bowyer Block, Singapore General Hospital" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Bowyer_Block%2C_SGH.JPG/220px-Bowyer_Block%2C_SGH.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Bowyer_Block%2C_SGH.JPG/330px-Bowyer_Block%2C_SGH.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Bowyer_Block%2C_SGH.JPG/440px-Bowyer_Block%2C_SGH.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bowyer_Block,_SGH.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Singapore_General_Hospital" title="Singapore General Hospital">
         Singapore General Hospital
        </a>
        Museum is housed in the "Bowyer Block"
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Singapore has a generally efficient healthcare system, even though their health expenditures are relatively low for developed countries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wyatt_256-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Wyatt-256">
        [255]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">
       World Health Organisation
      </a>
      ranks Singapore's healthcare system as 6th overall in the world in its
      <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Report" title="World Health Report">
       World Health Report
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHO_257-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WHO-257">
        [256]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In general, Singapore has had the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_infant_mortality_rate" title="List of countries by infant mortality rate">
       lowest infant mortality rate in the world
      </a>
      for the past two decades.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat2014births.26deaths_258-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-singstat2014births.26deaths-258">
        [257]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Life expectancy in Singapore is 80 for males and 85 for females, placing the country
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy#List_by_the_World_Health_Organization_.282011.29" title="List of countries by life expectancy">
       4th in the world for life expectancy
      </a>
      . Almost the whole population has access to improved water and
      <a href="/wiki/Sanitation" title="Sanitation">
       sanitation
      </a>
      facilities. There are fewer than 10 annual deaths from
      <a href="/wiki/HIV" title="HIV">
       HIV
      </a>
      per 100,000 people. There is a high level of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Immunisation" title="Immunisation">
       immunisation
      </a>
      . Adult obesity is below 10%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_259-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-259">
        [258]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The government's healthcare system is based upon the "3M" framework. This has three components: Medifund, which provides a safety net for those not able to otherwise afford healthcare,
      <a href="/wiki/Medisave" title="Medisave">
       Medisave
      </a>
      , a compulsory national
      <a href="/wiki/Medical_savings_account" title="Medical savings account">
       medical savings account
      </a>
      system covering about 85% of the population, and Medishield, a government-funded health insurance program.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wyatt_256-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Wyatt-256">
        [255]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Public hospitals in Singapore have autonomy in their management decisions, and compete for patients. A subsidy scheme exists for those on low income.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
       <a href="#cite_note-260">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2008, 32% of healthcare was funded by the government. It accounts for approximately 3.5% of Singapore's GDP.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
       <a href="#cite_note-261">
        [260]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
       Culture
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Singapore" title="Culture of Singapore">
       Culture of Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Singapore has one of the lowest rates of drug use in the world. Culturally, the use of illicit drugs is viewed as highly undesirable by Singaporeans, unlike many European societies. Singaporeans' disapproval towards drug use has resulted in laws that impose the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mandatory_death_sentence" title="Mandatory death sentence">
       mandatory death sentence
      </a>
      for certain serious
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Drug_trafficking" title="Drug trafficking">
       drug trafficking
      </a>
      offences. Singapore also has a low rate of alcohol consumption per capita and low levels of violent crime, and one of the lowest
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_intentional_homicide_rate" title="List of countries by intentional homicide rate">
       intentional homicide rate
      </a>
      globally. The average alcohol consumption rate is only 2 litres annually per adult, well below the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_alcohol_consumption_per_capita" title="List of countries by alcohol consumption per capita">
       world average
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Foreigners make up 42% of the population,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-un.org_190-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-un.org-190">
        [189]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat.gov.sg_215-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-singstat.gov.sg-215">
        [214]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and have a strong influence on Singaporean culture. The
      <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">
       Economist Intelligence Unit
      </a>
      , in its 2013 "
      <a href="/wiki/Where-to-be-born_Index#2013_rankings" title="Where-to-be-born Index">
       Where-to-be-born Index
      </a>
      ", ranks Singapore as having the best quality of life in Asia and sixth overall in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
       <a href="#cite_note-262">
        [261]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages.2C_religions.2C_and_cultures">
       Languages, religions, and cultures
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Singapore is a very diverse and young country. It has many languages, religions, and cultures for a country its size.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singapore21_263-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-singapore21-263">
        [262]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      When Singapore became independent from the United Kingdom in 1963, most of the newly minted Singaporean citizens were uneducated labourers from Malaysia, China and
      <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">
       India
      </a>
      . Many of them were transient labourers who were seeking to make some money in Singapore and they had no intention of staying permanently. A sizeable minority of middle-class, local-born people, known as the
      <a href="/wiki/Peranakan" title="Peranakan">
       Peranakans
      </a>
      , also existed. With the exception of the Peranakans (descendants of late 15th and 16th-century Chinese immigrants) who pledged their loyalties to Singapore, most of the labourers' loyalties lay with their respective homelands of Malaysia, China and India.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
       <a href="#cite_note-264">
        [263]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
       <a href="#cite_note-265">
        [264]
       </a>
      </sup>
      After independence, the process of crafting a Singaporean identity and culture began.
     </p>
     <p>
      Former Prime Ministers of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew and Goh Chok Tong, have stated that Singapore does not fit the traditional description of a
      <a href="/wiki/Nation" title="Nation">
       nation
      </a>
      , calling it a society-in-transition, pointing out the fact that Singaporeans do not all speak the same language, share the same religion, or have the same customs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singapore21_263-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-singapore21-263">
        [262]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
       <a href="#cite_note-266">
        [265]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Even though English is the first language of the nation, according to the government's 2010 census 20% of Singaporeans, or one in five, are
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illiterate" title="Illiterate">
       illiterate
      </a>
      in English. This is a marked improvement from 1990 where 40% of Singaporeans were illiterate in English.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat_a_267-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-singstat_a-267">
        [266]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
       <a href="#cite_note-268">
        [267]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Languages, religions and cultures among Singaporeans are not delineated according to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Skin_colour" title="Skin colour">
       skin colour
      </a>
      or
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancestry" title="Ancestry">
       ancestry
      </a>
      , unlike many other countries. Among Chinese Singaporeans, one in five is
      <a href="/wiki/Christian" title="Christian">
       Christian
      </a>
      , another one in five is
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheist" title="Atheist">
       atheist
      </a>
      , and the rest are mostly
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhists" title="Buddhists">
       Buddhists
      </a>
      or
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taoists" title="Taoists">
       Taoists
      </a>
      . One-third speak English as their home language, while half speak Mandarin Chinese. The rest speak other Chinese varieties at home. Most Malays in Singapore speak Malay as their home language with some speaking English.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat_a_267-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-singstat_a-267">
        [266]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Singaporean Indians are much more religious. Only 1% of them are atheists. Six in ten are Hindu, two in ten Muslim, and the rest mostly Christian. Four in ten speak English as their home language, three in ten
      <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">
       Tamil
      </a>
      , one in ten Malay, and the rest other
      <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_India" title="Languages of India">
       Indian languages
      </a>
      as their home language.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-singstat_a_267-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-singstat_a-267">
        [266]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Each Singaporean's behaviours and attitudes would therefore be influenced by, among many other things, his or her home
      <a href="/wiki/Language" title="Language">
       language
      </a>
      and his
      <a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">
       religion
      </a>
      . Singaporeans who speak English as their native language tend to lean toward
      <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">
       Western culture
      </a>
      , while those who speak Chinese as their native language tend to lean toward
      <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">
       Chinese culture
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">
       Confucianism
      </a>
      . Malay speaking Singaporeans tend to lean toward the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_Malays" title="Ethnic Malays">
       Malay culture
      </a>
      , which itself is closely linked to the
      <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">
       Islamic culture
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional center">
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:20px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chinese_New_Year_market.jpg">

          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          A scene in a street market in
          <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Singapore" title="Chinatown, Singapore">
           Chinatown, Singapore
          </a>
          , during the
          <a href="/wiki/Chinese_New_Year" title="Chinese New Year">
           Chinese New Year
          </a>
          holidays.
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:28px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_day_of_devotion_%E2%80%93_Thaipusam_in_Singapore_(4316108409).jpg">

          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          <a href="/wiki/Thaipusam" title="Thaipusam">
           Thaipusam
          </a>
          procession in Singapore
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:20px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Armenian_Church_Singapore_exterior.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Armenian_Church_Singapore_exterior.JPG/200px-Armenian_Church_Singapore_exterior.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Armenian_Church_Singapore_exterior.JPG/300px-Armenian_Church_Singapore_exterior.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Armenian_Church_Singapore_exterior.JPG/400px-Armenian_Church_Singapore_exterior.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          The
          <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Church,_Singapore" title="Armenian Church, Singapore">
           Armenian Church of Saint Gregory the Illuminator
          </a>
          —the oldest Christian church in Singapore
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:28px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Sultan_Mosque_at_Kampong_Glam,_Singapore_(8125148933).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1656" data-file-width="2464" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/The_Sultan_Mosque_at_Kampong_Glam%2C_Singapore_%288125148933%29.jpg/200px-The_Sultan_Mosque_at_Kampong_Glam%2C_Singapore_%288125148933%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/The_Sultan_Mosque_at_Kampong_Glam%2C_Singapore_%288125148933%29.jpg/300px-The_Sultan_Mosque_at_Kampong_Glam%2C_Singapore_%288125148933%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/The_Sultan_Mosque_at_Kampong_Glam%2C_Singapore_%288125148933%29.jpg/400px-The_Sultan_Mosque_at_Kampong_Glam%2C_Singapore_%288125148933%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          <a href="/wiki/Masjid_Sultan" title="Masjid Sultan">
           Sultan Mosque
          </a>
          in Singapore
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Attitudes_and_beliefs">
       Attitudes and beliefs
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      At the national level in Singapore,
      <a href="/wiki/Meritocracy" title="Meritocracy">
       meritocracy
      </a>
      , where one is judged based on one's ability, is heavily emphasised.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
       <a href="#cite_note-269">
        [268]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Racial and religious harmony is regarded by Singaporeans as a crucial part of Singapore's success, and played a part in building a Singaporean identity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
       <a href="#cite_note-270">
        [269]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Singapore has a reputation as a
      <a href="/wiki/Nanny_state" title="Nanny state">
       nanny state
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
       <a href="#cite_note-271">
        [270]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
       <a href="#cite_note-272">
        [271]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The national flower of Singapore is the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hybrid_plant" title="Hybrid plant">
       hybrid
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orchid" title="Orchid">
       orchid
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Vanda_%27Miss_Joaquim%27" title="Vanda 'Miss Joaquim'">
       Vanda 'Miss Joaquim'
      </a>
      , named in memory of a Singapore-born
      <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">
       Armenian
      </a>
      woman, who crossbred the flower in her garden at
      <a href="/wiki/Tanjong_Pagar" title="Tanjong Pagar">
       Tanjong Pagar
      </a>
      in 1893.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
       <a href="#cite_note-273">
        [272]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Many national symbols such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Singapore" title="Coat of arms of Singapore">
       Coat of arms of Singapore
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Lion_head_symbol_of_Singapore" title="Lion head symbol of Singapore">
       Lion head symbol of Singapore
      </a>
      make use of the
      <a href="/wiki/Lion" title="Lion">
       lion
      </a>
      , as Singapore is known as the
      <i>
       Lion City
      </i>
      . Other monikers by which Singapore is widely known is the
      <i>
       Garden City
      </i>
      and the
      <i>
       Red Dot
      </i>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Singapore" title="Public holidays in Singapore">
       Public holidays in Singapore
      </a>
      cover major Chinese, Western, Malay and Indian festivals.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
       <a href="#cite_note-274">
        [273]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Singaporean employees work an average of around 45 hours weekly, relatively long compared to many other nations. Three in four Singaporean employees surveyed stated that they take pride in doing their work well, and that doing so helps their self-confidence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
       <a href="#cite_note-275">
        [274]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
       Cuisine
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine" title="Singaporean cuisine">
       Singaporean cuisine
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market,_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg">
        <img alt="Satay stalls along Boon Tat Street next to Telok Ayer Market, better known as Lau Pa Sat" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg/220px-Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg/330px-Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg/440px-Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market%2C_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Satay_stalls_along_Boon_Tat_Street_next_to_Telok_Ayer_Market,_Singapore_-_20120629-02.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Lau_Pa_Sat" title="Lau Pa Sat">
         Lau Pa Sat
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Hawker_centre" title="Hawker centre">
         hawker centre
        </a>
        in the midst of the financial district.
        <a href="/wiki/Satay" title="Satay">
         Satay
        </a>
        cart-stalls rolls in after dusk, on a side street
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Dining, along with shopping, is said to be the country's national pastime.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
       <a href="#cite_note-276">
        [275]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The focus on food has led countries like Australia to attract Singaporean tourists with food-based itineraries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
       <a href="#cite_note-277">
        [276]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The diversity of food is touted as a reason to visit the country,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foodways_278-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Foodways-278">
        [277]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the variety of food representing different ethnicities is seen by the government as a symbol of its multiculturalism.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Martini_279-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Martini-279">
        [278]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The "national fruit" of Singapore is the
      <a href="/wiki/Durian" title="Durian">
       durian
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
       <a href="#cite_note-280">
        [279]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In popular culture, food items belong to a particular ethnicity, with Chinese, Malay, and Indian food clearly defined. However, the diversity of cuisine has been increased further by the "hybridisation" of different styles (e.g., the
      <a href="/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine" title="Peranakan cuisine">
       Peranakan cuisine
      </a>
      , a mix of Chinese and Malay cuisine).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foodways_278-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Foodways-278">
        [277]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">
       Arts
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay.jpg">
        <img alt="Domed performing arts centre with spikes reminiscent of a durian fruit" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="991" data-file-width="1496" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/The_Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay.jpg/220px-The_Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/The_Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay.jpg/330px-The_Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/The_Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay.jpg/440px-The_Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Esplanade performing arts centre, fronting
        <a href="/wiki/Marina_Bay,_Singapore" title="Marina Bay, Singapore">
         Marina Bay
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Since the 1990s, the government has been promoting Singapore as a centre for arts and culture, in particular the performing arts, and to transform the country into a cosmopolitan "gateway between the East and West".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281">
       <a href="#cite_note-281">
        [280]
       </a>
      </sup>
      One highlight was the construction of
      <a href="/wiki/Esplanade_%E2%80%93_Theatres_on_the_Bay" title="Esplanade – Theatres on the Bay">
       Esplanade – Theatres on the Bay
      </a>
      , a performing arts centre opened in October 2002.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
       <a href="#cite_note-282">
        [281]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The national orchestra,
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Symphony_Orchestra" title="Singapore Symphony Orchestra">
       Singapore Symphony Orchestra
      </a>
      , plays at the Esplanade. The annual
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Arts_Festival" title="Singapore Arts Festival">
       Singapore Arts Festival
      </a>
      is organised by the National Arts Council. The stand-up comedy scene has been growing, with a weekly
      <a href="/wiki/Open_mic" title="Open mic">
       open mic
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
       <a href="#cite_note-283">
        [282]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Singapore hosted the 2009
      <a href="/wiki/Gen%C3%A9e_International_Ballet_Competition" title="Genée International Ballet Competition">
       Genée International Ballet Competition
      </a>
      , a
      <a href="/wiki/Classical_ballet" title="Classical ballet">
       classical ballet
      </a>
      competition promoted by London's
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Dance" title="Royal Academy of Dance">
       Royal Academy of Dance
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
       <a href="#cite_note-284">
        [283]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Sport_and_recreation">
       Sport and recreation
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Singapore" title="Sport in Singapore">
       Sport in Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seating_at_Singapore_National_Stadium.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Seating_at_Singapore_National_Stadium.jpg/220px-Seating_at_Singapore_National_Stadium.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Seating_at_Singapore_National_Stadium.jpg/330px-Seating_at_Singapore_National_Stadium.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Seating_at_Singapore_National_Stadium.jpg/440px-Seating_at_Singapore_National_Stadium.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Seating_at_Singapore_National_Stadium.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/National_Stadium,_Singapore" title="National Stadium, Singapore">
         National Stadium
        </a>
        at the
        <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Sports_Hub" title="Singapore Sports Hub">
         Singapore Sports Hub
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Kallang" title="Kallang">
         Kallang
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Popular sports include football, basketball, cricket, swimming, sailing, table tennis and badminton. Most Singaporeans live in public residential areas (known as "
      <a href="/wiki/Public_housing_in_Singapore" title="Public housing in Singapore">
       HDB flats
      </a>
      ") near amenities such as public swimming pools, outdoor
      <a href="/wiki/Basketball_court" title="Basketball court">
       basketball courts
      </a>
      and indoor sport complexes. Water sports are popular, including sailing,
      <a href="/wiki/Kayaking" title="Kayaking">
       kayaking
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Water_skiing" title="Water skiing">
       water skiing
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Scuba_diving" title="Scuba diving">
       Scuba diving
      </a>
      is another popular recreational sport. The southern island of
      <a href="/wiki/Pulau_Hantu" title="Pulau Hantu">
       Pulau Hantu
      </a>
      , particularly, is known for its rich
      <a href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">
       coral reefs
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285">
       <a href="#cite_note-285">
        [284]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Singapore's
      <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
       football
      </a>
      league, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S-League" title="S-League">
       S-League
      </a>
      , launched in 1996,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286">
       <a href="#cite_note-286">
        [285]
       </a>
      </sup>
      currently comprises 9 clubs, including 2 foreign teams. The
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Slingers" title="Singapore Slingers">
       Singapore Slingers
      </a>
      , formerly the Hunter Pirates in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Australian_National_Basketball_League" title="Australian National Basketball League">
       Australian National Basketball League
      </a>
      , is one of the inaugural teams in the
      <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Basketball_League" title="ASEAN Basketball League">
       ASEAN Basketball League
      </a>
      which was founded in October 2009.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287">
       <a href="#cite_note-287">
        [286]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Singapore began hosting a round of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Formula_One_World_Championship" title="Formula One World Championship">
       Formula One World Championship
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Grand_Prix" title="Singapore Grand Prix">
       Singapore Grand Prix
      </a>
      , in 2008. The race takes place on the
      <a href="/wiki/Marina_Bay_Street_Circuit" title="Marina Bay Street Circuit">
       Marina Bay Street Circuit
      </a>
      and was the inaugural F1 night race,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-News_.E2.80.93_Singapore_confirms_2008_night_race_288-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-News_.E2.80.93_Singapore_confirms_2008_night_race-288">
        [287]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the first F1 street race in Asia.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1stStreet_289-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-1stStreet-289">
        [288]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Singapore Grand Prix will remain on the F1 calendar through at least 2017, after race organisers signed a contract extension with
      <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_Group" title="Formula One Group">
       Formula One Group
      </a>
      on the eve of the 2012 event.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
       <a href="#cite_note-290">
        [289]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Kranji_Racecourse" title="Kranji Racecourse">
       Kranji Racecourse
      </a>
      is run by the
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Turf_Club" title="Singapore Turf Club">
       Singapore Turf Club
      </a>
      and hosts multiple weekly meetings and many important local and international races, notably the prestigious
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Airlines_International_Cup" title="Singapore Airlines International Cup">
       Singapore Airlines International Cup
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Singapore also hosted the inaugural
      <a href="/wiki/2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics" title="2010 Summer Youth Olympics">
       2010 Summer Youth Olympics
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singapore_to_host_first_edition_of_the_Youth_Olympic_Games_in_2010_291-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Singapore_to_host_first_edition_of_the_Youth_Olympic_Games_in_2010-291">
        [290]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
       Media
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Singapore" title="Media of Singapore">
       Media of Singapore
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Companies linked to the government control much of the domestic media in Singapore.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_a_292-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse_a-292">
        [291]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MediaCorp" title="MediaCorp">
       MediaCorp
      </a>
      operates most
      <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Singapore" title="Television in Singapore">
       free-to-air television channels
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_radio_stations_in_Singapore" title="List of radio stations in Singapore">
       free-to-air radio stations
      </a>
      in Singapore. There are a total of seven free-to-air TV channels offered by Mediacorp.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
       <a href="#cite_note-293">
        [292]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The channels are
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MediaCorp_Channel_5" title="MediaCorp Channel 5">
       Channel 5 (English channel)
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Channel_NewsAsia" title="Channel NewsAsia">
       Channel News Asia (English channel)
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Okto" title="Okto">
       Okto
      </a>
      (English channel),
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MediaCorp_Channel_8" title="MediaCorp Channel 8">
       Channel 8 (Chinese channel)
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MediaCorp_Channel_U" title="MediaCorp Channel U">
       Channel U (Chinese channel)
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MediaCorp_Suria" title="MediaCorp Suria">
       Suria (Malay channel)
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MediaCorp_Vasantham" title="MediaCorp Vasantham">
       Vasantham (Indian channel)
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
       <a href="#cite_note-294">
        [293]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Starhub" title="Starhub">
       Starhub
      </a>
      Cable Vision (SCV) also offers cable television with channels from all around the world
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
       <a href="#cite_note-295">
        [294]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Singtel" title="Singtel">
       Singtel
      </a>
      's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mio_TV" title="Mio TV">
       Mio TV
      </a>
      provides an
      <a href="/wiki/IPTV" title="IPTV">
       IPTV
      </a>
      service.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
       <a href="#cite_note-296">
        [295]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Singapore_Press_Holdings" title="Singapore Press Holdings">
       Singapore Press Holdings
      </a>
      , a body with close links to the government, controls most of the newspaper industry in Singapore.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Media_297-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BBC_Media-297">
        [296]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Singapore's media industry has sometimes been criticised for being too regulated and lacking in freedom by human rights groups such as
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">
       Freedom House
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_a_292-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse_a-292">
        [291]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2014,
      <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">
       Reporters Without Borders
      </a>
      , a France-based international non-governmental organisation, ranked Singapore 153rd out of 180 nations in its
      <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">
       Press Freedom Index
      </a>
      . This was the lowest ranking for Singapore since the inception of this index
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
       <a href="#cite_note-298">
        [297]
       </a>
      </sup>
      in 2002. The
      <a href="/wiki/Media_Development_Authority" title="Media Development Authority">
       Media Development Authority
      </a>
      regulates Singaporean media, claiming to balance the demand for choice and protection against offensive and harmful material.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mica_299-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mica-299">
        [298]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Private ownership of TV satellite dishes is banned.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Media_297-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-BBC_Media-297">
        [296]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are 3.4 million users of the internet in Singapore,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Media_297-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-BBC_Media-297">
        [296]
       </a>
      </sup>
      one of the highest internet penetration rates in the world. The Singapore government does not engage in widespread censoring of the internet,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
       <a href="#cite_note-300">
        [299]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but it maintains a list of one hundred websites (mostly pornographic) that it blocks as a "symbolic statement of the Singaporean community's stand on harmful and undesirable content on the Internet".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
       <a href="#cite_note-301">
        [300]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As the block covers only home internet access, users may still visit the blocked websites from their office computers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
       <a href="#cite_note-302">
        [301]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
       See also
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright" role="navigation" style="margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em;border:solid #aaa 1px">
      <ul style="display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold">
       <li style="display:table-row">
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center">

        </span>
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle">
         <a href="/wiki/Portal:Singapore" title="Portal:Singapore">
          Singapore portal
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li style="display:table-row">
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asia_(orthographic_projection).svg">
          <img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="541" data-file-width="541" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/28px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/42px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/56px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" width="28"/>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle">
         <a href="/wiki/Portal:Asia" title="Portal:Asia">
          Asia portal
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li style="display:table-row">
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Terrestrial_globe.svg">
          <img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="312" data-file-width="321" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6b/Terrestrial_globe.svg/29px-Terrestrial_globe.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6b/Terrestrial_globe.svg/43px-Terrestrial_globe.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6b/Terrestrial_globe.svg/58px-Terrestrial_globe.svg.png 2x" width="29"/>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle">
         <a href="/wiki/Portal:Geography" title="Portal:Geography">
          Geography portal
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </div>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
       Notes
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
      <ol class="references">
       <li id="cite_note-153">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-153">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         "Most-awarded" usually refers to a lifetime, unless a time-frame is stated.
        </span>
       </li>
      </ol>
     </div>

       <li id="cite_note-112">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-112">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          <a class="external text" href="http://eurocham.org.sg/index.php?option=com_eurochammobile&amp;view=news&amp;id=289&amp;template=ccmobile" rel="nofollow">

        <span class="reference-text">

         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-2010censuspercentage_198-2">
          <sup>

          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">

       <li id="cite_note-213">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-213">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          Tan Hwee Hwee (22 July 2002).

          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASingapore&amp;rft.au=Chee+Beng+Tan&amp;rft.au=Wu%2C+David+Y.H.&amp;rft.btitle=Changing+Chinese+foodways+in+Asia&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fhl%3Den%26lr%3D%26id%3Dp5Mw_WTLhiYC%26oi%3Dfnd%26pg%3DPA161%26dq%3Dsingapore%2A%2Bcuisine&amp;rft.isbn=978-962-201-914-0&amp;rft.pages=161+ff.&amp;rft.place=Hong+Kong&amp;rft.pub=Chinese+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-Martini-279">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-Martini_279-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation journal">

          <a class="external text" href="http://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst?docId=5002403690" rel="nofollow">

         </sup>
        </span>

        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASingapore&amp;rft.atitle=Nation%27s+History&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fapp.www.sg%2Fwho%2F4%2FOur-History.aspx&amp;rft.jtitle=Singapore+Infomap&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation web">
         <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070823024237/http://www.moe.gov.sg/prime/prime.htm" rel="nofollow">
          "MOE-PRIME"
         </a>
         .
         <i>
          Programme For Rebuilding and Improving Existing schools (PRIME)
         </i>
         . Archived from
         <a class="external text" href="http://www.moe.gov.sg/prime/prime.htm" rel="nofollow">
          the original
         </a>
         on 23 August 2007
         <span class="reference-accessdate">
          . Retrieved
          <span class="nowrap">
           15 May
          </span>
          2007
         </span>
         .
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASingapore&amp;rft.atitle=MOE-PRIME&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.moe.gov.sg%2Fprime%2Fprime.htm&amp;rft.jtitle=Programme+For+Rebuilding+and+Improving+Existing+schools+%28PRIME%29&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation pressrelease">
         <a class="external text" href="http://www.moe.gov.sg/press/2007/pr20070214.htm" rel="nofollow">
          "Eight More Schools to Benefit from Upgrading"
         </a>
         (Press release). Ministry of Education. 14 February 2007
         <span class="reference-accessdate">
          . Retrieved
          <span class="nowrap">
           15 May
          </span>
          2007
         </span>
         .
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASingapore&amp;rft.btitle=Eight+More+Schools+to+Benefit+from+Upgrading&amp;rft.date=2007-02-14&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.moe.gov.sg%2Fpress%2F2007%2Fpr20070214.htm&amp;rft.pub=Ministry+of+Education&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
        <sup class="noprint Inline-Template">

                articles
               </a>

              <div id="25px.C2.A0Geographic_locale" style="font-size:114%">
               <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gnome-globe.svg">

               Geographic locale

             <td colspan="2">

            <tr>
             <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" colspan="2" style="width:100%;padding:0px;font-size:114%;">
              <div style="padding:0px;">
               <b>
                <a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">
                 Lat.
                 <small>
                  and
                 </small>
                 Long.
                </a>
                <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion">
                 <a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Singapore&amp;params=1_22_N_103_48_E_">
                  <span class="geo-default">
                   <span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
                    <span class="latitude">
                     1°22′N
                    </span>
                    <span class="longitude">
                     103°48′E
                    </span>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                  <span class="geo-multi-punct">
                   ﻿ / ﻿
                  </span>
                  <span class="geo-nondefault">
                   <span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
                    1.367°N 103.800°E
                   </span>
                   <span style="display:none">
                    ﻿ /
                    <span class="geo">
                     1.367; 103.800
                    </span>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </a>
                </span>
               </b>
               <div aria-labelledby="Countries_and_dependencies_of_Asia" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px">
                <table class="nowraplinks collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit">
                 <tr>
                  <th class="navbox-title" colspan="3" scope="col">
                   <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
                    <ul>
                     <li class="nv-view">
                      <a href="/wiki/Template:Countries_of_Asia" title="Template:Countries of Asia">
                       <abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;" title="View this template">
                        v
                       </abbr>
                      </a>
                     </li>
                     <li class="nv-talk">

                      <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">
                       ASEAN
                      </a>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">
                       G-77
                      </a>

                       Non-Aligned Movement

                     </li>
                     <li class="nv-talk">
                      <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Template talk:Non-Aligned Movement">
                       <abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;" title="Discuss this template">
                        t
                       </abbr>
                      </a>
                     </li>
                     <li class="nv-edit">
                      <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Non-Aligned_Movement&amp;action=edit">
                       <abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;" title="Edit this template">
                        e
                       </abbr>
                      </a>
                     </li>
                    </ul>
                   </div>

                           </li>

                            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_where_English_is_an_official_language" title="List of countries where English is an official language">
                             List of countries where English is an official language
                            </a>
                           </li>
                          </ul>

            <tr>
             <th class="navbox-group" scope="row">
              Summer Youth Olympics
             </th>
             <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
              <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
               <b>
                <a href="/wiki/2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics" title="2010 Summer Youth Olympics">
                 2010
                </a>
               </b>
               :
               <strong class="selflink">
                Singapore
               </strong>
               •
               <b>
                <a href="/wiki/2014_Summer_Youth_Olympics" title="2014 Summer Youth Olympics">
                 2014
                </a>
               </b>
               :
               <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">
                Nanjing
               </a>
               •
               <i>
                <b>
                 <a href="/wiki/2018_Summer_Youth_Olympics" title="2018 Summer Youth Olympics">
                  2018
                 </a>
                </b>
                :
                <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">
                 Buenos Aires
                </a>
               </i>
              </div>
             </td>
            </tr>
            <tr style="height:2px">
             <td colspan="2">
             </td>
            </tr>

                </i>
                *
               </li>
               <li>
                <b>
                 <a href="/wiki/Yerevan" title="Yerevan">
                  Yerevan
                 </a>
                </b>
                ,
                <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">
                 Armenia
                </a>
                *
               </li>
              </ul>
             </div>
            </td>
           </tr>
          </table>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr style="height:2px">
        <td colspan="2">
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2" style="padding:0.5em 0 0.3em; line-height:1.3em;">
         <div>
          <b>
           *
          </b>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transcontinental_country" title="Transcontinental country">
           Transcontinental country
          </a>
          .
          <br/>
          <b>
           †
          </b>
          See:
          <a href="/wiki/Positions_on_Jerusalem" title="Positions on Jerusalem">
           Positions on Jerusalem
          </a>
          . Both Israel and Palestinians claim Jerusalem as capital.
          <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">
           Jerusalem
          </a>
          contains the Israeli parliament and almost all Israeli government ministries.
          <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">
           Tel Aviv
          </a>
          contains most foreign embassies in Israel;
          <a href="/wiki/Ramallah" title="Ramallah">
           Ramallah
          </a>
          is the administrative seat of the Palestinian Authority.
          <br/>
          <b>
           +
          </b>
          According to the 1947
          <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the Republic of China">
           Constitution of the Republic of China
          </a>
          , Nanjing is the official capital of the ROC, with Taipei as the
          <a href="/wiki/Temporary_capital" title="Temporary capital">
           seat of government
          </a>
          . See also
          <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Taiwan" title="Political status of Taiwan">
           Political status of Taiwan
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
     </div>
